results.title: What is nothing?
results.creator_credit: William C. Crain and Barr Films
results.brief_description: Two young boys explore many ways to use the word “nothing” as they search for its meaning in the dictionary and during their everyday activities.

results.title: Building a house: where does it come from?
results.creator_credit: Charles Cahill and Charles Cahill and Associates
results.brief_description: Describes the men and material involved in building a home and traces the manufacturing processes used in producing the materials and products used in home construction.

results.title: World of darkness
results.brief_description: Edited from the motion picture entitled ‘Strange creatures of the night’, the film examines a variety of creatures, including bats, owls, and a blind lizard that live and hunt in the darkness. Excellent footage of the animals in their natural environment. There is an information booklet inside each can.

results.title: Stained glass: painting with light
results.brief_description: Artists and master craftsmen are shown designing and constructing stained-glass windows and lampshades. Explores both traditional and contemporary examples of this art form.

results.title: Man, monsters and mysteries
results.creator_credit: Les Clark, Ken Peterson and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Discusses how humans invented monsters through fear and ignorance and how science attempts to unravel these mysteries. Looks at the history of the Loch Ness Monster. Partly animated. Suitable for primary level.

results.title: The Huntsman
results.creator_credit: Douglas Jackson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film adaptation of a short story by Toronto writer David Lewis Stein about a ten-year-old boy who ferrets out golf balls from the rough, then sells his findings to passing golfers. There is an unexpected development when two unscrupulous older boys try to muscle in on his business. A children’s film, but one that many adults will enjoy.

results.title: Bighorn: Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep, Banff and Jasper National Parks
results.creator_credit: Bill Schmalz, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A far closer view, and a more complete one, than even the hardiest and most patient of visitors is likely to get of the bighorn mountain sheep of the Canadian Rocky Mountains. “Bighorn” is a film distinguished by its camerawork (Bill Schmalz). It catches the characteristic behavior of the bighorns from birth to mating time. Few animals are more arresting in appearance or activity than these dancers of the high ledges. Awards: Novi Sad; Spindleruv Mlyn; Philadelphia; Tarbes.
